newsitem.title: USA: Hilton launches $6.5 billion bid for ITT.
newsitem.headline: Hilton launches $6.5 billion bid for ITT.

text.p: Hilton Hotels Corp., the nation's largest hotel and gambling company, offered Monday to acquire ITT Corp. for $6.5 billion in cash and stock.

Including the assumption of debt, the deal is valued at $10.5 billion. In a letter to ITT, Hilton offered to pay $6.5 billion in cash and stock and assume $4 billion in debt, creating the world's largest lodging and gaming company.
ITT, owner of the Sheraton hotel chain and Caesars World Casinos, was not immediately available to comment on the unsolicited offer.
Industry analysts said the proposed deal could be a boon for Hilton.

"It's a blockbuster of a deal and would make a tremendously strong lodging and gaming company," said Dennis Forst, financial analyst at Sutro & Co. He said the $55 a share price would be a good buy for Hilton shareholders but ITT shareholders might want more given ITT shares had traded in the mid-60's back in August.
Because of the deal's size it might raise eyebrows of state gambling regulators and the Justice Department, Forst added.
In December, Hilton acquired Bally Entertainment Corp. for $3 billion.
Under terms of the ITT proposal, Hilton is offering to buy half of ITT's outstanding shares for $55 a share in cash and the other half for $55 a share in Hilton common stock.
The offer, which represents a 29 percent premium over ITT's current stock price around $42 a share, could be raised after a full review of ITT's operations, Hilton said.

"The combination of ITT and Hilton would bring together two of the world's leading lodging companies as well as two premier gaming businesses," Hilton Chief Executive Officer Stephen Bollenbach said in a statement.

Hilton made the offer to ITT management in a phone conversation Monday. In a formal letter delivered later Hilton said it preferred to work with ITT management, but was prepared to try to unseat the ITT board if necessary to complete the deal.

ITT's operations include 415 hotels and 130,000 rooms. Its gambling business operates 14 casinos across the country. Hilton's hotel business includes 240 properties with 100,000 rooms. It also operates 16 casinos.

Hilton said it has entered into a side agreement with HFS Inc., a hotel franchisor and owner of the Avis rental car chain, under which it would license the Sheraton name and management agreements to HFS for HFS to operate.
Hilton estimated it could cut as much as $100 million in annual costs from the merged operations.
Bollenbach said ITT's return to shareholders has been "disappointing" when compared to the Standard & Poor's index of 500 leading companies and to other comparable companies in the lodging industry.
He said Hilton would look at selling off non-strategic assets such as the New York Knicks professional basketball team and New York Rangers hockey team.

ITT currently has over a $3 billion capital expenditure program in place to update hotels and casinos in Las Vegas and Atlantic City. A substantial portion of that program would be unnecessary if the two companies combined, Hilton said.
The stock of ITT jumped to $58 in after-hours trade from Monday's earlier close of $42.625. Hilton shares ended down 50 cents at $25.25.
